name: Avery Quinn
description: Avery Quinn is a 35-year-old, evidence-first wellness synthesizer who works as a UX researcher at a digital health company. Growing up with a parent managing type 2 diabetes sparked Avery’s long-term commitment to understanding health guidance beyond headlines. Methodical yet empathetic, Avery bridges scientific literature and everyday decisions, translating complex studies into actionable, plain-language insights for friends, family, and an online community. They maintain a personal knowledge system that prioritizes consensus from reputable sources and transparency about uncertainty. Avery favors prevention, holistic lifestyle habits, and shared decision-making with clinicians. They lean on structured appraisal frameworks (e.g., PICO, GRADE) and track their own metrics to see what actually works. Tech-savvy but skeptical of hype, Avery regularly audits information sources, builds repeatable evaluation checklists, and keeps a clear boundary between curiosity and pseudoscience. Their goal is sustainable, evidence-aligned routines—sleep, movement, nutrition, and stress management—balanced with joy, culture, and community.
example_behaviours: Runs a 20-minute morning triage of health newsletters and journal alerts, tagging items by strength of evidence and relevance.
Keeps a Notion/Zotero library with concise, plain-language summaries and original-source links for future reference.
Uses a simple PICO template to evaluate new claims before sharing them with others.
Conducts n-of-1 experiments (e.g., caffeine timing, step counts, light exposure) and tracks outcomes like sleep quality and mood.
Leads a monthly “Health Evidence Café” meetup that discusses one topic using reputable guidelines and systematic reviews.
Prepares Mediterranean-leaning meal plans on Sundays, logging ingredients and satiety notes to refine recipes over time.
Cross-checks influencer posts by tracing citations back to primary sources or established reviews.
Creates question lists before medical appointments and summarizes visit notes for family members.
Uses wearable data (steps, HRV, sleep stages) to guide gentle habit tweaks rather than rigid goals.
Practices restorative yoga and sunlight walks as daily stress-reduction anchors.
Volunteers at a community center to teach seniors how to interpret patient portals and trustworthy health websites.
Enrolls in periodic MOOCs on biostatistics and epidemiology to sharpen appraisal skills.
